Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a several-month history of episodic chest discomfort. He describes this as a vague 'fullness' or 'pressure,' sometimes in the center of his chest, occasionally feeling more like indigestion in his upper abdomen. These episodes occur 2-3 times a week, typically lasting 5-10 minutes. He initially found no clear trigger, noting it sometimes after large meals or during stressful periods at work. However, over the last month, he has noticed it twice when walking briskly uphill. He has tried over-the-counter antacids, which provided minimal and inconsistent relief. He denies any previous similar episodes of this nature.

Secondary_Symptoms: Mild shortness of breath with episodes

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension, diagnosed 5 years ago, currently treated. Hyperlipidemia, diagnosed 3 years ago, on medication. No history of diabetes mellitus, myocardial infarction, stroke, or gastroesophageal reflux disease. No previous surgeries.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an accountant, reports significant work-related stress, especially during tax season. Former smoker, quit 15 years ago (10 pack-year history). Consumes 2-3 glasses of wine per week. States he tries to follow a 'reasonably healthy' diet but admits to periods of poor eating habits due to stress. Not regularly physically active.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Lisinopril 10mg once daily, Atorvastatin 20mg once daily. Denies use of other prescription, over-the-counter (other than occasional antacids), or herbal medications.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, productive cough, or hemoptysis. Denies frank heartburn, acid regurgitation, dysphagia, odynophagia, nausea beyond occasional mild feeling with discomfort, vomiting, or significant change in bowel habits. Denies melena or hematochezia. Denies sharp, tearing, or consistently pleuritic chest pain. Denies palpitations, syncope, or orthopnea. Denies leg swelling, calf pain, or claudication. Denies focal weakness, numbness, or dizziness. Denies recent trauma.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of severe chest discomfort, which she describes as a 'deep, squeezing ache' located primarily in the substernal area, with some radiation to the epigastrium. The discomfort started gradually after dinner (a takeaway pizza) and has been constant with intermittent waves of increased intensity, currently rated 7/10. She feels nauseous and has had one episode of non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting about 30 minutes ago, which did not relieve the discomfort. She reports feeling somewhat sweaty. She denies any clear relation of this pain to exertion or specific movements. She has had milder episodes of 'bad indigestion' or 'upper abdominal discomfort' over the past few months, usually lasting an hour or so after eating rich foods, but never this severe or with this chest component. She tried an over-the-counter antacid an hour ago with no relief. Denies shortness of breath, palpitations, dizziness, or pain radiating to her left arm or jaw. No cough or fever.

Secondary_Symptoms: Pain worse after fatty meal (tonight's pizza)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of sudden onset severe central chest pain. He describes the pain as an intense, deep 'squeezing' or 'constricting' sensation, rated 9/10 in severity. The pain radiates to his upper back, between the shoulder blades, and also somewhat to his jaw. It has been constant since onset. Associated symptoms include diaphoresis, nausea, and a profound feeling of 'impending doom'. He reports one episode of near-syncope when he tried to stand up shortly after the pain started. He tried taking one of his wife's sublingual nitroglycerin tablets approximately 30 minutes ago, with no relief. He denies any recent trauma or strenuous activity preceding the pain.

Secondary_Symptoms: Radiation to upper back and jaw

ECG.Findings: Sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm. Left ventricular hypertrophy by voltage criteria (Sokolow-Lyon). Non-specific ST segment depression of 0.5mm in leads II, III, aVF, and V4-V6. No pathological Q waves. No acute ST elevation meeting STEMI criteria.

Chest_X_Ray_Portable_AP.Findings: Cardiac silhouette is at the upper limits of normal size. Mediastinal contour appears prominent in the aortic knob region, but definitive assessment of widening is limited by AP portable technique and patient rotation. Lungs are clear. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Echocardiogram_Focused_Bedside.Findings: Left ventricular hypertrophy noted. Global left ventricular systolic function appears preserved, estimated ejection fraction 55-60%. No clear regional wall motion abnormalities. Aortic root measured at 4.2 cm (dilated). A possible subtle, linear, undulating structure (flap?) seen intermittently in the proximal ascending aorta; views significantly limited by patient habitus and distress. No significant pericardial effusion (trace, <5mm posterior fluid noted).

CT_Angiogram_Chest_Abdomen_Pelvis_with_I.Findings: Stanford Type A aortic dissection. An intimal flap is identified originating approximately 1 cm distal to the aortic valve annulus, spiraling through the ascending aorta, aortic arch, and extending into the proximal descending thoracic aorta. The dissection flap involves the origin of the brachiocephalic artery, with evidence of compromised flow to its branches. The true and false lumens are visualized. The aortic root diameter is 4.3 cm. The dissection extends inferiorly to the level of the abdominal aorta, just above the bifurcation. The right renal artery appears to arise predominantly from the false lumen with attenuated contrast opacification. A small circumferential pericardial effusion, measuring up to 5mm in thickness, is present. No evidence of frank rupture or active extravasation. Lungs clear. Other visualized abdominal organs unremarkable.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Cardiovascular: Stanford Type A aortic dissection

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-week history of intermittent left-sided chest discomfort. They describe it as a 'catching' or 'pulling' sensation, localized to the left lower anterior chest wall, near the ribs. Episodes occur sporadically, about 2-3 times per week, typically lasting from a few seconds up to a minute. The patient notes it sometimes occurs when slouching at their desk for prolonged periods or when attempting a sudden deep inspiration, but the association is not consistent. The pain is rated as 4/10 intensity and can be sharp when it occurs. It does not radiate. They deny true shortness of breath but mention a sensation of 'not being able to get a full breath in' during the episodes. There is no associated cough, fever, chills, or night sweats. The patient denies palpitations, syncope, or near-syncope. There is no exertional component to the pain and no associated diaphoresis. They deny recent trauma or any unusually strenuous physical activity. No leg swelling or calf pain reported. The patient also mentions some mild, intermittent epigastric discomfort over the past few weeks, which they attributed to stress; they tried an over-the-counter antacid on one occasion without clear benefit for either the chest or epigastric symptoms. They are concerned due to a family history of heart disease.

Secondary_Symptoms: Catching or pulling sensation in chest

Exercise_Stress_Test_ECG_Bruce_protocol.Findings: Patient exercised for 9 minutes (Stage 3), achieving 10 METs and 95% of maximum predicted heart rate. Test terminated due to patient reporting chest discomfort similar to presenting symptoms and fatigue. ECG showed sinus tachycardia, occasional premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) during recovery. No ischemic ST segment depression (achieved <1mm horizontal ST depression in V5, V6). Blood pressure response appropriate initially (rose from 130/80 mmHg to 170/85 mmHg), then a slight drop in systolic BP to 160/85 mmHg at peak exertion despite increasing workload, before recovery. Chest discomfort resolved within 3 minutes of recovery. No significant arrhythmias during exercise.

CT_Coronary_Angiogram.Reason_for_exam: Exertional chest pain with non-diagnostic stress test findings, to definitively rule out coronary artery disease.
CT_Coronary_Angiogram.Findings: Dominant right coronary artery. No evidence of atherosclerotic plaque or obstructive coronary artery disease. Coronary calcium score of 0. Normal origin and course of coronary arteries. Non-cardiac structures unremarkable.

Echocardiogram_Transthoracic_with_Dopple.Findings: Left Ventricle: Asymmetric septal hypertrophy noted, with maximal interventricular septal thickness of 1.9 cm (normal <1.1 cm), particularly in the basal and mid-septum. Posterior wall thickness 1.0 cm. LV cavity size normal. LV systolic function globally preserved, LVEF estimated at 65%. No regional wall motion abnormalities at rest. Evidence of diastolic dysfunction (Grade 1: impaired relaxation). Right Ventricle: Normal size and systolic function (TAPSE 2.2 cm). Valves: Mitral valve shows mild systolic anterior motion (SAM) without significant mitral regurgitation at rest (trace MR). No significant LVOT obstruction at rest (peak gradient <10 mmHg). Aortic valve structurally normal, no stenosis or regurgitation. Tricuspid and pulmonic valves normal. Pericardium: No pericardial effusion. Inferior Vena Cava: Normal diameter and collapsibility. Impression: Findings consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, non-obstructive type at rest. Features of systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve are present without significant resting outflow tract obstruction. Mild diastolic dysfunction.
